WRITING.TEXT:
I recently switched over to a corsair H55 closed loop system (from an old air cooler) to give some more overclocking headroom.
I took the opportunity to switch out a lot of my 5 yo fans from he case with (what I thought) newer more efficient and quieter fans.
Now the whole system is way louder than it used to be, while a lot of it seems to be the air pushing through the radiator, the combination of the other fans seems to be louder overall too.
The main culprit was the stock H55 fan which creates a constant buzz but even with that replaced. There's still an ambient whirr that wasn't as noticeable before. Even with the fans turned to half speed.
Y? And what can I try?
That makes sense. For the money it looks like they overclock easily to 4+ GHz. Should last me a little while until it's worth overhauling the entire system

Totally get you. I'm saving up to build an x99 workstation PC for freelance work (3D animation). An i7 6850k with 4x 1080ti's But that isn't for a year or or so yet.
I'm just looking at squeezing a little more juice from my old gaming system and it looked like this was a good way to go about it.
Looks like under 100 for each on ebay.

WRITING.TITLE: Differences between Xeon W3680 and X5680
WRITING.TEXT:
I've noticed some suggestions in a couple of threads about buying an older xeon chip to OC on a LGA 1366 mobo. Two good options look like the X5680 and the W3680. They look similar in spec but I'm wondering which will be better for the actual use ...overclocking and gaming. (and whether there's any better chips out there also that my setup will support)
My mobo is an Asus P6x58d-e and I've been running an i7 930 since they came out. Instead of a full overhaul right now it would be great to get more milage out of the current system by simply OC'ing an old Xeon. Especially as I've got access to a couple of GTX titans through work that are being severely bottlenecked at the moment with the old chip.
Well the DJI ronin 2 does look to be a step up from its predecessor. Will the increased price and the limited availability from hire companies sway the decision however? Fuck knows any fuck cares.

WRITING.TITLE: Goop Machine
Carbot

WRITING.TEXT:
When working with particle systems its a good idea to have two separate versions of the objects your working with.
So here you will have one version the pipes that are the ones you're going to render (with bits cut out etc). But no collider tag, they are simply to look nice.
Then you will have a copy of the piper with no cutouts that you will use as the collider (maybe with fewer polygons if possible to speed up the system). To make sure they don't render you can add a compositing tag and just turn everything off.
Its always a good idea to work with a separate collider object as they can afford to be much lower resolution which will greatly increase your simulation speed.

WRITING.TITLE: Looking for an art book lost to my childhood.
WRITING.TEXT:
I remember having a book when i was a kid full of cool spaceship illustrations. Unfortunately I cant remember a whole lot about it but I saw an image just today that took my memory right back and I'd love to find a copy of that book again!
It looks like it was a collection of sci-fi book front covers from the 70s but I'm 100% sure it didn't have the title text of each book.
[I've managed to track down some of the books the covers were from so here are a few.](http://imgur.com/a/TV7X1)
Maybe a lot of them are Tony Roberts but I'm not convinced it was a collection solely of his work.
Maybe it really is truly lost to my childhood but I'd love to find it again!

WRITING.TITLE: Explosive Leg Training for Downhill
WRITING.TEXT:
I was wondering what you guy's suggestions are for off the bike training with regards to the explosive and tensional strength needed for riding downhill. That is, more time pedaling and absorbing shocks with your bum off the seat.
This weekend I went for my first trails ride of the season and i was surprised how quickly my legs got tired when not sat on the saddle. Rock climbing, swimming, road bikes and dirt jumping has trained my stamina quite well over winter, (upper body strength isn't an issue and I can pedal uphill in the saddle for ever). But there's definitely something missing.
Perhaps there's some specific weight training or other regimen that will help over the season to train the fast twitch leg muscles necessary for downhill?
Always leave them wanting more... :)
Also looks like puep.

WRITING.TEXT:
Lightness and linkage systems that make it a lot easier to pedal uphill before hucking downhill. Thats the only direction we're moving in really.
What i meant was, top of the line at any given point seems like the pinnacle of technology. But sales cycles must continue for companies to stay in business so patents are held back and tech drip fed for the biggest marketing impact.

It's worth noting the trickle down effect new technologies have on sports especially like mtb. This may seem super expensive and out there now but if you told someone 10 years ago we would all be riding the kind of bikes we have commonplace now they'd look at you with wide eyed speculation.
You're welcome. We're all constantly learning and I'm sure I'll look back on these projects in a year and be all "what was I thinking!" but until then!

[A lot of cities are switching over to LED street lamps in place of the old Amber colored low pressure sodium lamps.](http://gizmodo.com/led-streetlights-will-change-hollywood-and-make-every-c-1514840416) Lighting is a huge part of cinema and this will likely change the entire mood of city shots in the future, just as it did when changing from purpley blue lights to the current amber ones in the 70s and 80s

Fried chicken. It will be a cold day in hell before I give that shit up.
Recipe time:
Blend up your stale bread with a tonne of paprika and garam masala. Slice up your chicken breast and jook it up in flour. Douse it in whisked egg then coat in breadcrumbs. Shallow fry those badbuoies for a couple of minutes on each side, punch with salt and pepper and enjoy with a side of chilli mayo. You're welcome.

It's fairly powerful especially when you want to animate fov.

There's a pretty simple way to do it in R14 and above with the morph camera object.
Just create your two camera's, one being a frontal view that you want to animate to. Select your 2 (or more) ceres and go to create-camera morph. You'll be given another camera with a slider that you can animate to morph between the two cameras you created.
Always leave them wanting more...

All the animation was done inside of C4D minus the fireworky bits towards the end (that was Particular). In ae I did a small amount of time remapping just to perfectly sync certain frames then just some colour correction and compositing ie, light leak stock and messing with alpha channels.
Cinema 4D for 3d modelling, animation and rendering. Then compositing, colour correction etc in After Effects.
I've not used that. Thrausi has been pretty useful in the past. It simply chops up your models and apply the various tags. Then you can do as you wish with your dynamics and mograph.

I used Thrausi to cut up a column model i built exclusively for the purpose. Then it was just a case of making all the pieces trigger rigid body on impact and have a big invisible ball crash into the column.
You're not too far off. I've been doing a tonne of 3d work the past couple of months so this is a personal project grabbing lots of elements from old projects.

Its mainly 3D animation and then some compositing to bring it all together.
I use Cinema 4D for the 3D design, animation and rendering. Then the exports are brought into After Effects for colour correction, naling down the timing, fixing small errors and adding extra elements like the colour burns on the blacks and the fireworky elements near the end (before the cannons).

WRITING.TITLE: How To Get Into Diving?
WRITING.TEXT:

I should mention I'm 25.
